results.title: Guide to Canberra
results.creator_credit: Colin Dean and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Produced by the Commonwealth Film Unit in 1958, ‘Guide to Canberra’ was initially intended to inform public servants transferring to Canberra about the lifestyle that they could expect to find in our nation’s growing capital. The glowing report that ensues takes the viewer on a tour of the city’s significant sites, its relaxed shopping districts and new suburban homes, offering a snapshot of Canberra at a time when its population was just 40,000 strong. With its planned transport network, new schools, established retailers and infant café culture, Canberra is depicted as a modern and prosperous city, all the more appealing for the sense of balance afforded by its graceful bushland setting. Whether you view our nation’s capital with affection, indifference or antipathy, this upbeat film leaves little room for doubt that Canberra is unlike any other city in Australia.

results.title: Switch on Bigga
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Electricity Commission of New South Wales (N.S.W.), Stanley Hawes, Lee Robinson and Australia. Dept. of the Interior. Film Division
results.brief_description: A unique look at the coming of electric power to a small rural district in NSW and the benefits derived from electricity by the farmer and his family. Includes a country style grand switching on ceremony.

results.title: On the Line
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson, SBS-TV and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: It’s a harsh, lonely life for the men, mostly European migrants, who work maintaining the railway around Redmont in north-west Western Australia. Labouring through searing heat over 426 kilometres of mountainous, desert region, these men talk candidly about their lives, providing psychological and social insight into what it is to be living in “isolation”.

results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.

results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: Witness
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Through intermingling static images of a playground, the beach and the town, David Greig paints a picture of Apollo Bay, on the west coast of Victoria, that is evocative and nostalgic.

results.title: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Neal Benezra, director of San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA), talks about the history of the institution with regards to its upcoming expansion. Benezra tells the story of his journey to find the architects who designed the expansion and explains the thinking behind the vision for the building.

This talk featured as part of the ‘William Kentridge: Five Themes’ exhibition public programs events. The exhibition was originally curated by SFMOMA in 2009 and has since travelled to New York, Paris, Vienna, Jerusalem and Moscow.

results.title: Fire and water
results.creator_credit: Bill Runting, Pip Starr and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description:
Roxby Downs, in South Australia and run by Western Mining (later BHP Billiton), is the world’s largest uranium mine. It also sits on sacred Aboriginal land and proposals to increase production were considered to have possibly severe implications. The population and culture of the Arabunna and Koktha people could be effected, as could environmental and ecological concerns such as local water levels and quality.

In September 1997, the music festival ‘Roxstop’ was held to prevent these developments to the mine. In amongst the protests and celebrations, activists went on a company-hosted tour of the mine to learn how Western Mining justify their position on expanding operations.

results.title: Fight for Country
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description: In 1998, over 5,000 people travelled to Kakadu, in the Northern Territory, to stand alongside the traditional owners of the land, the Mirrar people, and lend their support to the Jabiluka Campaign. The fight to prevent the development of the Jabiluka uranium mine was one of the biggest protest movements in Australia’s history and over 600 people were arrested in the process. It took film-maker Pip Starr four years to make this film, including one year spent documenting these historic events.

results.title: Atomic footprints
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr and Pip Starr Productions
results.brief_description:
The debate surrounding the production of nuclear energy goes back to the bombing of Hiroshima at the end of World War II. Since then, the proliferation of nuclear energy and weapons has been used as a deterrant, a bolstering of military power and, in the early 2000’s, as a solution to combat global warming.

With the Prime Minister John Howard’s comments regarding not ruling out atomic power stations, this documentary considers the implications to the environment, the people living on the land, our health and our future.
